text: Hwang H, Kim S, Lee S, Park T (2024). gesca: Generalized Structured Component Analysis Structural Equation Modeling. R package version 1.0.5, https://quantmm.github.io/gesca/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {gesca: Generalized Structured Component Analysis Structural Equation Modeling},   author = {Heungsun Hwang and Sunmee Kim and Sungyoung Lee and Taesung Park},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 1.0.5},   url = {https://quantmm.github.io/gesca/}, }

title: Generalized Structured Component Analysis Structural Equation Modeling
text: R package gesca implements Generalized Structured Component Analysis (GSCA) basic extensions, including constrained single multiple group analysis, second order latent variable modeling. enables users obtain overall local model fit measures, parameter estimates bootstrapped standard errors confidence intervals, total indirect effects latent variables indicators. package allows users easily specify hypothesized relationships among latent variables /indicators using intuitive, text-based syntax. user-friendly syntax involves use indicator names simple numerical operators, making straightforward accessible users. Currently, gesca offers basic GSCA methods, .e., component-based structural equation modeling, wherein constructs represented components weighted sums observed variable. interested recently developed GSCA methods, GSCA measurement errors (GSCA_M) integrated GSCA (IGSCA), highly recommend GSCA Pro. free software provides graphical user interface, making simpler model path diagrams visualize results effectively. committed continuous development gesca R package plan soon incorporate latest GSCA methods, including features similar found GSCA Pro. Stay tuned exciting updates!

title: Generalized Structured Component Analysis Structural Equation Modeling
text: Quick overview component-based structural equation modeling GSCA Pro webpage list key references

title: Generalized Structured Component Analysis Structural Equation Modeling
text: latest development version can installed github: Install CRAN: use Posit Cloud (previously RStudio Cloud), can directly access use package via link.

title: Generalized Structured Component Analysis Structural Equation Modeling
text: quick examples using main function built-dataset
code: library(gesca) data(gesca.rick2)  # Model specification myModel <- "         # Measurement model          OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3         OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3         AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3         AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8                  # Structural model          OI ~ OP         AC_J ~ OI         AC_L ~ OI "  # A single-group analysis rick2.GSCA <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2) summary(rick2.GSCA)  # Run a multiple-group GSCA with the grouping variable gender: GSCA.group <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender") summary(GSCA.group)

what: Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
title: Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
text: user-specified structural equation model, function calculates total indirect effects (1) latent variables latent variables structural model (2) latent variables indicators measurement model.

title: Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
text: object object class. can created via gesca.run function.

title: Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
text: bootstrapped standard errors provided total indirect effects. user can specify number bootstrap samples via gesca.run function. number bootstrap samples equal 0, standard errors provided.

title: Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
text: Four matrices whose row column names names indicators latent variables.

title: Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
text: Hwang, H., & Takane, Y. (2014). Generalized Structured Component Analysis: Component-Based Approach Structural Equation Modeling (pp.119-123). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC Press.

title: Total and Indirect Effects of Variables — effectmeasures
code: if (FALSE) {  library(gesca) data(gesca.rick2) # Organizational identification example of Bagozzi  # Model specification myModel <- "     # Measurement model     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3     OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3     AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3     AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC_J ~ OI     AC_L ~ OI "  # Run a multiple-group GSCA with the grouping variable gender: GSCA.group <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender") summary(GSCA.group)    # default output effectmeasures(GSCA.group)  # total and indirect effects per group GSCA.group.nbt0 <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender", nbt = 0) effectmeasures(GSCA.group.nbt0)  # no bootstrapped standard error of parameters  # Second-order latent model with formative indicators SndForm <- "     # Measurement model     OP(0) =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3 + cei4 + cei5 + cei6 + cei7 + cei8     OI(0) =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3 + ma4 + ma5 + ma6     AC_J(0) =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3 + orgcmt7     AC_L(0) =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Second-order latents     AC(0) =: AC_J + AC_L      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC ~ OI "  SndFormFit <- gesca.run(SndForm, gesca.rick2, "gender") summary(SndFormFit) effectmeasures(SndFormFit) # Total/Indirect effects of latent variables on indicators # will not be provided and instead, be reported as "NULL".  }

what: Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
title: Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
text: function provides six model fit indices (FIT, Adjusted FIT, GFI, Standardized Root Mean Square, FIT_M, FIT_S) user-specified model.

title: Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
text: object object class. can created via gesca.run function.

title: Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
text: FIT indicates much variance indicators latent variables explained user-specified model. AFIT takes account number parameters calculating explained variance. GFI SRMR measure closeness sample covariances covariances reproduced model parameter estimates. GSCA, separate model fit measures measurement structural models available: FIT_M FIT_S. FIT_M assesses much variance indicators explained measurement model, whereas FIT_S calculates much variance latent variables accounted structural model. six indices given bootstrapped standard errors confidence intervals. number bootstrap samples equal 0, standard errors reported. user can specify number bootstrap samples via gesca.run function.

title: Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
text: Numeric values six model fit indices: numbers parameters bootstrap samples, six fit indices bootstrapped standard errors confidence intervals.

title: Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
text: Hwang, H., & Takane, Y. (2014). Generalized structured component analysis: Component-Based Approach Structural Equation Modeling (pp.26-32). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC Press.

title: Indices for Assessment of Model Fit — fitmeasures
code: if (FALSE) { library(gesca) data(gesca.rick2) # Organizational identification example of Bagozzi  # Model specification myModel <- "     # Measurement model     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3     OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3     AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3     AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC_J ~ OI     AC_L ~ OI "  # Run a multiple-group GSCA with the grouping variable gender: GSCA.group <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender", nbt=50) summary(GSCA.group)  # default output shows model fit indices as well, but fitmeasures(GSCA.group)  # this gives bootstrapped std errors and CI }

title: Bagozzi's organizational identification example — gesca.rick2
text: example part organizational identification data used Bergami Bagozzi (2000). data used Hwang Takane (2014) (see Chapter 3). data contain sample 305 employees (male = 157 female = 148) 22 indicators.

title: Bagozzi's organizational identification example — gesca.rick2
Bagozzi's organizational identification example — gesca.rick2
text: data frame 305 observations following 22 variables. gender grouping variable - gender (1 = male, 2 = female) cei1 First indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige cei2 Second indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige cei3 Third indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige cei4 Fourth indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige cei5 Fifth indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige cei6 Sixth indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige cei7 Seventh indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige cei8 Eighth indicator associated first latent variable - Organizational Prestige ma1 First indicator associated second latent variable - Organizational Identification ma2 Second indicator associated second latent variable - Organizational Identification ma3 Third indicator associated second latent variable - Organizational Identification ma4 Fourth indicator associated second latent variable - Organizational Identification ma5 Fifth indicator associated second latent variable - Organizational Identification ma6 Sixth indicator associated second latent variable - Organizational Identification orgcmt1 First indicator associated third latent variable - Affective Commitment-Joy orgcmt2 Second indicator associated third latent variable - Affective Commitment-Joy orgcmt3 Third indicator associated third latent variable - Affective Commitment-Joy orgcmt7 Fourth indicator associated third latent variable - Affective Commitment-Joy orgcmt5 First indicator associated fourth latent variable - Affective Commitment-Love orgcmt6 Second indicator associated fourth latent variable - Affective Commitment-Love orgcmt8 Third indicator associated fourth latent variable - Affective Commitment-Love

title: Bagozzi's organizational identification example — gesca.rick2
text: Bergami, M., & Bagozzi, R. P. (2000). Self-categorization, affective commitment group self-esteem distinct aspects social identity organization. British Journal Social Psychology, 39(4), 555-577. Hwang, H., & Takane, Y. (2014). Generalized Structured Component Analysis: Component-Based Approach Structural Equation Modeling (pp.112-119). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC Press.

title: Bagozzi's organizational identification example — gesca.rick2

what: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
title: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
text: Fit generalized structured component analysis (GSCA) model. gesca 1.0 can handle various extensions GSCA, including imposing constraints parameters, second-order latent variable modeling, multiple-group analysis, calculation total indirect effects, missing value imputation.

title: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
code: gesca.run(myModel, data, group.name = NULL, group.equal = NULL,           nbt = 100, itmax = 100, ceps = 1e-5,           moption = 0, missingvalue = -9999)

title: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
text: myModel simple description user-specified model using gesca model syntax. model can described strings multiple lines formulas. See Details Examples . data data matrix frame including observed variables used myModel. group.name character string used multiple group analysis. variable name data frame defines group membership case. user can specify variable used provide group memberships multiple group analysis. NULL (default), single-group GSCA run. group.equal vector character strings used multiple group analysis. can one following: "loadings" "paths", specifying pattern equality constraints across multiple groups. default set NULL (default), assuming parameters freely estimated group. See Details Examples . nbt Denote number bootstrap samples. gesca 1.0, bootstrap method employed obtain standard errors parameter estimates. default, nbt set 100, non-negative numeric value can used. number bootstrap samples equal 0, values parameter estimates obtained original dataset reported without standard errors CIs. itmax maximum number iterations alternating least-squares (ALS) algorithm. default value set 100. ceps Convergence threshold ALS algorithm. default set 0.00001. moption Options handling missing data. default, assumed value missing variables. gesca 1.0 currently offers three options handling missing data choice one following: list-wise deletion (moption = 1), mean substitution (moption = 2), least-squares imputation (moption = 3). missingvalue missing value identifier. used moption specified. default, every element -9999 data defined missing value. Users can use numeric integer value specify missing values data. See Examples .

title: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
text: General Overview gesca Model Syntax: gesca 1.0, user can write one formula lines specify structural equation model. gesca model syntax gesca.run function. model syntax consists character strings multiple lines formulas follows: 1) specify relationships indicators latent variables, user can use =~ operator. example, model syntax Y =~ X1 + X2 + X3 means latent variable Y related indicators X1, X2, X3. 2) relationships among latent variables can expressed ~ operator. example, syntax Y1 ~ Y2 + Y3 shows Y1 regressed Y2 Y3. 3) user can consider second-order latent variable linked set first-order latent variables. can described =: operator. example, syntax H1 =: Y1+Y2+Y3 indicates second-order latent variable, H1, related lower-order latent variables Y1, Y2, Y3. Importantly, variable names gesca model syntax correspond variable names data frame. option group.name used multiple-group GSCA, model structure fitted across groups default. Constraining Parameters gesca Model Syntax: user wants fix constrain parameters constants, can done gesca model syntax adding values labels followed * operator. example, following model syntax, path coefficients L1 regressed L4 L4 regressed L5 fixed 0.01 0.6, respectively: myModel <-  " L1 =~ z1 + z2 + z3 L2 =~ z4 + z5 + z6 L3 =~ z7 + z8 L4 =~ z9 + z10 + z11 L5 =~ z12 L2 ~ L1 L3 ~ L1 + L2 L4 ~ 0.01*L1 + L2 + L3 L5 ~ 0.6*L4 " model identical following model using labels (instead values): myModel <-  " L1 =~ z1 + z2 + z3 L2 =~ z4 + z5 + z6 L3 =~ z7 + z8 L4 =~ z9 + z10 + z11 L5 =~ z12 L2 ~ L1 L3 ~ L1 + L2 L4 ~ c1*L1 + L2 + L3 L5 ~ c2*L4 c1 == 0.01 c2 == 0.6 " Constraining Parameters Multiple-Group GSCA: across-group equality constraints can imposed parameters way . addition, group.equal option can used constrain loadings /path coefficients across groups simultaneously. demonstrate imposition across-group equality constraints loadings path coefficients, user can simply input group.equal = c("loadings", "paths"), gesca.run function estimates single set loadings path coefficients fixed equal across groups. Similarly, group.equal = c("loadings") treats loadings fixed across groups, group.equal = c("paths") returns identical path estimates group. See Examples details. Reflective/Formative Indicators gesca Model Syntax: gesca 1.0, relationships indicators latent variables can either reflective formative can defined operator (1) (0), respectively. user can input operators model syntax lines contain =~ /=: operators. (1) (0) argument omitted, default, gesca.run function treat relationships defined =~ /=: reflective. example, model syntax Y =~ X1 + X2 Y(1) =~ X1 + X2 means X1 X2 reflective. Similarly, second-order latent variable effects first-order latent variables, relationship can defined H1 =: Y1+Y2 H1(1) =: Y1+Y2. hand, first-order latent variables considered formative, model syntax expressed Y(0) =~ X1 + X2, involves loadings X1 X2. Missing Value Imputation: use missing value identifier gesca.run function, missing values data frame represented numeric codes (e.g. -9999, 99, -9) specified missingvalue option. can used moption argument used. data missing value codes user omits missingvalue argument, gesca.run function treat missing values regular data values (except value -9999 default).

title: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
text: object class gesca.run, summary method four functions gesca 1.0 (effectmeasures, fitmeasures, latentmeasures, qualmeasures) available.

title: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
text: Hwang, H., & Takane, Y. (2014). Generalized structured component analysis: Component-Based Approach Structural Equation Modeling (pp.13-126). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC Press.

title: Fit Structural Equation Models using Generalized Structural Component Analysis — gesca.run
code: if (FALSE) { library(gesca) data(gesca.rick2) # Organizational identification example of Bagozzi                   # has the grouping variable "gender"  # Model specification myModel <- "     # Measurement model     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3     OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3     AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3     AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC_J ~ OI     AC_L ~ OI "  # In case the user wants to apply a single-group analysis ignoring the group information: rick2.GSCA <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2)  # Run a multiple-group GSCA with the grouping variable gender: GSCA.group <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender") summary(GSCA.group) GSCA.group.nbt0 <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name ="gender", nbt = 0) summary(GSCA.group.nbt0)    # no bootstrapped std errors effectmeasures(GSCA.group.nbt0)  # Models with the imposition of constraints on parameters across groups # (1) equality constraints equl.cstr <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name ="gender",                         group.equal = c("loadings", "paths"))  # (2) identical loadings but different path coefficients equl.loadings <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name ="gender",                             group.equal = c("loadings"))  # (3) More constraints across groups with some formative indicators myModel.con <- "     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3     OI(0) =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3     AC_J =~ c(g,g)*orgcmt1 + c(h,h)*orgcmt2 + c(i,i)*orgcmt3     AC_L(0) =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      OI ~ 0.37*OP     AC_J ~ OI     AC_L ~ OI " Const.Form <- gesca.run(myModel.con, gesca.rick2, group.name ="gender", nbt = 50) summary(Const.Form)   # Second-order latent variable modeling myModel5 <- "     # Measurement model     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3 + cei4 + cei5 + cei6 + cei7 + cei8     OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3 + ma4 + ma5 + ma6     AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3 + orgcmt7     AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Second-order latents     AC =: AC_J + AC_L      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC ~ OI "  second.GSCA <- gesca.run(myModel5, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender") summary(second.GSCA) second.GSCA.nbt0 <- gesca.run(myModel5, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender", nbt=0) summary(second.GSCA.nbt0)  }

what: Means, Variances, and Correlations of Latent Variables — latentmeasures
title: Means, Variances, and Correlations of Latent Variables — latentmeasures
text: means variances latent variables correlations among latent variables. gesca 1.0, individual scores latent variables calculated based Fornell's (1992) approach.

text: object object class. can created via gesca.run function.

text: Numeric vectors means variances, correlation matrices.

title: Means, Variances, and Correlations of Latent Variables — latentmeasures
text: Fornell, C. (1992). national customer satisfaction barometer, Swedish experience. Journal Marketing, 56, 6-21. Hwang, H., & Takane, Y. (2014). Generalized structured component analysis: Component-Based Approach Structural Equation Modeling (p.26). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC Press.

title: Means, Variances, and Correlations of Latent Variables — latentmeasures
code: if (FALSE) { library(gesca) data(gesca.rick2) # Organizational identification example of Bagozzi  # Model specification myModel <- "     # Measurement model     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3     OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3     AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3     AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC_J ~ OI     AC_L ~ OI "  # Run a multiple-group GSCA with the grouping variable gender: GSCA.group <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender", nbt=50) latentmeasures(GSCA.group) }

title: Reliability and Validity Measures — qualmeasures
text: Cronbach's alpha Dillon-Goldstein's rho (composite reliability) can used checking internal consistency indicators latent variable. average variance extracted (AVE) can used examine convergent validity latent variable. number eigenvalues greater one per block indicators can used check uni-dimensionality indicators.

code: if (FALSE) { library(gesca) data(gesca.rick2) # Organizational identification example of Bagozzi  # Model specification myModel <- "     # Measurement model     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3     OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3     AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3     AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC_J ~ OI     AC_L ~ OI "  # Run a multiple-group GSCA with the grouping variable gender: GSCA.group <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender", nbt=50) qualmeasures(GSCA.group) }

what: A Summary and Parameter Estimates of a Fitted Model — summary.gesca
title: A Summary and Parameter Estimates of a Fitted Model — summary.gesca
text: summary fitted model model fit measures parameter estimates obtained GSCA.

title: A Summary and Parameter Estimates of a Fitted Model — summary.gesca
A Summary and Parameter Estimates of a Fitted Model — summary.gesca
text: object function prints nice summary fitted model gesca.run function, including (1) information convergence alternating least-squares (ALS) algorithm, (2) number observations (per group), parameters, bootstrap samples, (3) six model fit measures, (4) GSCA parameter estimates weights, loadings, path coefficients, (5) R-squared values endogenous latent variable. ... arguments passed methods.

title: A Summary and Parameter Estimates of a Fitted Model — summary.gesca
text: Object values general information parameter estimates fitted model via gesca.run function.

title: A Summary and Parameter Estimates of a Fitted Model — summary.gesca
text: Hwang, H., & Takane, Y. (2014). Generalized structured component analysis: Component-Based Approach Structural Equation Modeling (p.26). Boca Raton, FL: Chapman & Hall/CRC Press.

title: A Summary and Parameter Estimates of a Fitted Model — summary.gesca
code: if (FALSE) { library(gesca) data(gesca.rick2) # Organizational identification example of Bagozzi  # Model specification myModel <- "     # Measurement model     OP =~ cei1 + cei2 + cei3     OI =~ ma1 + ma2 + ma3     AC_J =~ orgcmt1 + orgcmt2 + orgcmt3     AC_L =~ orgcmt5 + orgcmt6 + orgcmt8      # Structural model     OI ~ OP     AC_J ~ OI     AC_L ~ OI "  # Run a multiple-group GSCA with the grouping variable gender: GSCA.group <- gesca.run(myModel, gesca.rick2, group.name = "gender", nbt=50) summary(GSCA.group)  }
